This game investigates deep issues of sociology:
What do you do when you have to rely on the idiot masses to not be idiots in order to survive? When the people in power may or may not be competent, may or may not be trustworthy? Transformice answers all these questions, and more.

Unfortunately this is overshadowed by a horrible community, and even worse community leaders. I attempted to explain what I was doing, and offered to show them, but I was shot down and never heard from them again.

Because of this experience, I can't recommend this game to anybody. Even though the game is free-to-play, it's just not worth the frustration.

Been playing this game for a year now, and I'm glad to finally have a chance to review it.

Basically, TFM is a well put together game. It has a lot of inherently interesting game-theory choices involving the debate between cooperation and individual selfishness as well as a very high, and enjoyable, technical skillcurve to master.

That being said, the absolutely toxic community on this game makes it nigh unplayable, and I constantly tell my friends not to even try it, because it's had such a negative impact on my life. What could be an entirely solid platforming MMO is anchored heavily by the fact that the moderation staff is unpaid and thus entirely negligent, so bouts of intense racism, sexism, homophobia, anti-semitism, as well bullying in the forms of physical and sexual threats are a daily unchecked plague on every server.

Additionally, the Steam port is extremely laggy, and I've had to select items multiple times just to get them to summon while being Shaman.

So i've been playing TFM since about June 2011 or so. I've seen it change. A lot. Thought I should type up a review for it.

The game itself seem pretty simple at first glance. You play as a little mouse, going through obstacle courses to get the cheese and bring it back to the hole. However, there is a SHARP learning curve to this game. Learning how to Shaman (player that builds/summons bridges and helps the mice get to the cheese and back) is a very VERY important skill needed to have a good time in this game. However the tutorial never even touches on how it's done. You're pretty much thrown into a public server with no idea what's going on. Nice!

My huge pet peeve with this game is the community however. The community is HORRIBLE. I won't strech on it but let's just say its rampant with pre-teens/teens who think they're cool for using offensive language/slurs. Yeah. Fun

What keeps me from leaving the game however is the concept overall, once you get past the learning curve (and the obnoxious main chat), it can be a pretty fun way to pass the time. Plus hey, if you're willing to drop some cash on in-game currency, you can make some cool looking outfits.

Bottom Line, I have mixed Feelings for Transformice. If you're willing to google how to work the game and accept the community, then highly reccomend it!

Transformice is a cute little game, with hours of your time to be wasted.

I've only started playing this a few months ago, and i've noticed the lack of educated Shamans, so ill list some controls that are basically need-to-know towards the bottom, and ill link their website's tutorials.

The goal of this game?
Getting cheese. It's pretty much the currency, and is used to buy aesthetic items like hats, skins, clothes, and building block re-skins for the shaman. The only problem i have with this, is that a lot of things cost thousands upon thousands of cheese, which can be quite a grind.

Unlike a lot of 'F2P' games, the only thing that spending money does, is get you the before-mentioned aesthetic items, and plays no factor in whether you'll be good or not.
Sometimes you get cheese, sometimes you completely miss a jump and fall to your doom. That's the cruel reality of Transformice.

There are a few game modes, and levels with different mechanics (Like Soul-Mate levels [which you'll learn to hate]), but the premise of the game never really changes. You're collecting cheese to level up, and buy shiny things.

Oh, and speaking of leveling up, lets talk about the shamans skill tree. There's 3 categories to work your way up in, one focuses on saving the poor mice that have fallen or gotten stuck, while another focuses on making sure YOU stay alive. The last is completely mechanic based, making anvils weigh more, or giving you a larger radius to place things.
Gaining skill points is fairly quick, but leveling your shaman is another story as it counts how many mice you have saved and how quickly you can save them all.

reviewText:
The concept of this game is very simple: You're a mouse, go grab the cheese and then back to the hole.
However, there's much more hiding beneath that, which you can only find out by giving this game a try.
The developers are struggling to offer you as many updates and events as possible in order to ensure you the best gaming experience. The game is also not full of bugs as some may say. It's natural to expect bugs on occasions, but I haven't seen any major bug in a long time and they usually get fixed pretty quickly once they are spotted. The variety of game modes makes the gameplay itself even more interesting and appealing.

The design of the game is also very appealing and there's already a large collection of Transformice fanart on the Internet and a solid amount of players that have stuck up to the community for these more than five years. The customizable items is also an important aspect that makes this game very unique. The shop has a smart marketing strategy which allows you to buy most items either with fraises (which can be bought with real money) or cheese (which is only obtainable by playing). So even if you don't have money, you can still obtain the article you wanted for free if you gather cheese. There are also items that can be bought with cheese only, which encourages players to play the game in order to be able to buy them.

The opinions are split when it comes to changes: some prefer the old Transformice, some like the new one more. Either way, the concept of the game has always remained the same, just that the game has way more features than it used to have back when it was first released. Some updates may be silly, some may be great. But no matter what, this is not just an experience for us as players, but also an experience for the developers.

reviewText:
As a fan of this game for a long while, I can honestly say that the game has not changed much at all. This can be interpereted in many different ways, as the game is not changing so much that people who play the game around 2010 like I have won't stop playing because it's too different.

The basis of the game is a simple collect and return game where you either have to use skillful tactics (such as the wall jump) or the help of a shaman (In the normal and vanilla modes) to get the cheese and return (or find) the hole to return the cheese to. Every time you collect cheese, you earn +1 Cheese to spend in a store. The store has access to many customisation options (Compared to 2010 when I played, they added A LOT more) for you to create a mouse that you want.

For the people who want a challenge, after saving a specific number of mice (1000 mice) you can get access to a hard mode, where you are not allowed to use a red(global) anchor (the most stable anchor in the game) which is used in many bridges (and as a new addition, a new mode that removes all anchors but blue anchors, which tests the true skill of a shaman for experts).

Because the game is very fun already, there is no need for drastic changes, and because people are allowed to create their own levels, and a mode specifically for the earlier levels that were before the game allowed custom levels for those veterans who want to play the older maps.

There are a handful of modes in this game from the menu (There are unofficial ones but I will be adressing the mod-created ones because people don't often play custom modes):

- Normal is your standard game with levels that are new, old and created by other people. These include racings levels and art levels, and can be played with a shaman and some without the shaman's help.
- Vanilla is your standard game but with only old levels that are officially approved/created by the developers. This is an easy way to create cheese but lacks much challenge.
- Survival is a game mode that allows a shaman to try to kill the mice. This is a skilful mode which requires you to know a bit about the games physics and tricks to stop trolling, but is also great practice.
- Racing is a game mode that is similar to the standard gamemodes, but instead of using a shaman, uses many levels that depend on the person's skill and speed. This is a competetive mode where people compete to come in the top 3. This is great practice to get faster at the game and to beat levels first commonly without the help of a shaman if possible.

-Bootcamp is the hardest mode in the game. This is a game mode that is similar to the standard gamemodes, but instead requires extreme skill and almost precice movement to pass a level. This is a mode that requires a large amount of knowledge of the games mechanics, like wall jumping, jumping off corners to create momentum and things in levels like advantages of trampolines and other things.

I reccomend this game for anyone who wants to pass time!

reviewText:
Remember that chaotic little game you played back in 2010?  The one with mice and cheese and cannonballs?  So many cannonballs...  Well, it's back... in Steam form!

The objective of this game is simple: Get the cheese, bring it back to the mouse hole.  However, that's only the beginning.  To get to the cheese, you might need to use purple trampolines, climb chocolate bars, avoid (or even use) hot lava, or even contend with jealous shaman bent on keeping you from your goal!  All this while playing with a handful of other players, live!

Since 2010, this game gained a cult following, keeping fans of old and gaining fans anew.  These days, it's much the same as it always was... but with far more game modes, such as Race, Survival, and Defilante (Scrolling)!  It also has much more user-created content than it used to, such as maps and even wearable items for your mouse!  That's right: You can customize your mouse with items to set them apart from the rest of the crowd!  But you've gotta earn 'em by getting the cheese, first!  Or, ya know... buying fraises (strawberries), the microtransaction currency of the game, with real-world money. (The prices are actually pretty good, too!)

If you like side-scrolling action/puzzle games with an adorable twist and some amount of customization, or are just an occasional fan of absolute chaos, this is definitely the game for you!

reviewText:
This is the one game I've played for nearly 5 years now and which I still enjoy. It's the perfect combination between casual fun on one side and the ability to communicate with others on the other side. This game is highly community driven thanks to the Map Editor, the LUA integration, the possibility to voteban people from the room if they're annoying. It's even possible to play moderator if you wish and check out reports other players made using the tribunal.

Sure, it's a pretty simple 2d game and it may not be as immersive as more elaborate games. But that's sometimes exactly what you should be looking for as it gives you plenty of time to chat up with other players. If you ask me, that's where a lot of other games go wrong. Not everything is perfect here and occasionally there are server issues or bugs, but in the end they get resolved and at least that means we get to laugh at Tig (one of the creators and known as a troll).

Do I recommend this game? Yes I do. I've found it to be the perfect place to make a lot of good friends and that to me is extremely important in a game. So yes, go make friends!

Transformice is a really nice game, but even though the community isn't forgiving (as half of the reviews have mentioned here) once you are able to get a hang of the basic manouveres in-game, it's really fun to play.  Since I started playing back in 2011, I've only seen the game get better ever since it started out from the small selection of around 100 or so default maps.  Now, there are way over 1 million community maps, and most of them are playable.

Transformice gives you a selection of game mode to play from.
Vanilla - Servers in vanilla mode only contain the game's original maps (and event maps if it is a time of year)
Normal - Servers with normal mode contain the vanilla maps, and the community maps (all types of community maps)
Racing - Racing has a very simple goal - To get the cheese to the hole first. (Community racing maps)
Survivor - As a mice, you have to survive from the shaman as the shaman has to kill everybody within a time limit. Survive to gain more points
And there are some more game-modes, but most aren't play as much.

Really though, you should play Transformice in the end.  The maps are fun to play, the events that sometimes unfold during maps are hilarious, and once you get used to basic game mechanics, the community is nice as well.
10/10

reviewText:
When I first saw this game on Kongregate, it was something of an odd ball. Just make up some name, jump in, and the servers would connect you with a couple dozen other players going through the same dozen maps to collect cheese and bring it to the hole. Simple. I first thought of it as some odd sociology expiriment, as almost all the maps at the time seemed to be testing the players. Half of them allowed players to go very quickly through it, but doing so would jeporadize the other mice. I didn't expect it to last a year, and yet in the year 2015, it stands.

So what's changed since then? Well, the community makes maps, of which there are now thousands of unique ones. Shamen have been given more interesting puzzles to work with, combined with skill trees to make interesting possibilities, along with Hard and Divine mode. Mod support is in, shown through the wide variety of rooms you can join. If you want to hone your skills as a normal mouse, Bootcamp will whip you into shape. If you want to be able to survive troll shamen, Survivor can show you the tricks to that. Music allows for users to submit Youtube videos to be watched by all the occupants, and there's more yet. Tribes are a thing, if you want to have friends collaborate for fun. The cosmetics channel true TF2 spirit by allowing you to alter the appearance of your mouse with a long line of items that all can be bought with in-game cheese. Events are brought about every holiday of the year, adding some new aspect to the game. Emotes became a thing, so you no longer need to pretend to sit or cry, because you can actually sit and cry.

And you know what? It doesn't seem to be stopping. It just keeps going, showing true devotion to the style of having a simple, fun game. Just by playing as a mouse, getting some nice, tasty cheese.

reviewText:
When I first saw this game on Kongregate, it was something of an odd ball. Just make up some name, jump in, and the servers would connect you with a couple dozen other players going through the same dozen maps to collect cheese and bring it to the hole. Simple. I first thought of it as some odd sociology expiriment, as almost all the maps at the time seemed to be testing the players. Half of them allowed players to go very quickly through it, but doing so would jeporadize the other mice. I didn't expect it to last a year, and yet in the year 2015, it stands.

So what's changed since then? Well, the community makes maps, of which there are now thousands of unique ones. Shamen have been given more interesting puzzles to work with, combined with skill trees to make interesting possibilities, along with Hard and Divine mode. Mod support is in, shown through the wide variety of rooms you can join. If you want to hone your skills as a normal mouse, Bootcamp will whip you into shape. If you want to be able to survive troll shamen, Survivor can show you the tricks to that. Music allows for users to submit Youtube videos to be watched by all the occupants, and there's more yet. Tribes are a thing, if you want to have friends collaborate for fun. The cosmetics channel true TF2 spirit by allowing you to alter the appearance of your mouse with a long line of items that all can be bought with in-game cheese. Events are brought about every holiday of the year, adding some new aspect to the game. Emotes became a thing, so you no longer need to pretend to sit or cry, because you can actually sit and cry.

And you know what? It doesn't seem to be stopping. It just keeps going, showing true devotion to the style of having a simple, fun game. Just by playing as a mouse, getting some nice, tasty cheese.

The gameplay is simple and addicting with a high skill ceiling, you are a mouse trying to get the cheese back to the hole. Each round has a time limit of 2 minutes. The game offers great replayability, having over 200 official maps, and millions of maps made by the community, using the level editor. When you get cheese back in the hole you earn points, at the beginning of each round, the mouse with the most points will be the Shaman. The Shaman is able to spawn items such as boxes, planks, portals, trampolines, balloons, balls, anvils, and even spirits. The Shaman can use different anchors and make objects invisible in order to create constructions. The Shaman decides if he will save the mice and bring them to safety, or just ruin everything. Collecting cheese and saving mice will give you experience, used to unlock Shaman abilities in your skill tree. There are 5 different skill trees, the Mechanic, the Spiritual Guide, the Wind Master, the Wildling and the Physicist. As you earn more saves, you will unlock hard mode and divine mode which are harder, more challenging modes for Shamans. When you get cheese, firsts, save mice, complete bootcamps or take part in special events you will unlock titles. You can choose a title to display under your mouse's name. Your cheese and firsts gathered, mice saved, bootcamps completed and titles unlocked will be shown in your profile, making you want to play more to make your profile better. Cheese gathered is used in the shop to buy accesories, which can be equipped in head, ears, eyes, mouth, neck, tail, change your color and your fur and even customize Shaman items. The items can be customized, you can change the color however you want. You can even buy outfits, which save a combination of items made by you. The game is not pay to win, you have no advantage over the other players if you buy ''fraises'' and everything can be unlocked with cheese. This game offers an amazing character customization. You can create tribes which are basically groups players can join. You can chat, stay in your tribe house and even play youtube videos in it. This game is a great to just chat with your friends and troll around. You can create a room, mess around, chat while gathering a few cheese. As the game progresses you will learn advanced tehniques which require skill, such as wall-jumping, corner jumping, spirit jumping, turn-arounds, etc.  It will be pretty hard and confusing at first, but you will get used to it. You will never get bored of Transformice, there are 7 different game modes: Vanilla, community made maps, survivor, racing, music, bootcamp, defilante and 15+ mini games like prop hunt, hide and seek, tower defense, deathmatch, infected, traitor, football and others. On the other hand,the negative aspect of the game is the community. The community used to be very nice and friendly. Nowdays, people rage a lot and will usually call you a noob, a lucker or even worse if you get a first. They will be especially toxic against new players who don't know how to play Shaman.

Graphics are simple, and they look pretty nice and cute. The game got a lot of improvements since it got released. The sound is not the best, it only has a soundtrack which some people might find annoying and a few sound effects.

I recommend this game, very fun, addicting, give it a try, 9/10.

reviewText:
Transformice is a game about collecting cheese and bringing it back to the mouse hole. The main mechanics are physics based like walljumping, corner jumping, some walls can be climbed, but some can't because they are too slippery etc. ice. These skills can be aquired after you've played the game for a while and observed other player's movements. There are several different gamemodes, some and mostly player made. As you collect cheese your cheese counter will rise and you will be able to buy cosmetic items in the shop. You also score points when you manage to collect a cheese and bring it back home. These points build up as you collect more cheese in a room. Getting first gives you more points. Eventually you will have the highest number of points and you will be chosen as the shaman. The shaman's job is to help the mice collect their cheese and get home safely. Shamans have the power to summon objects in the game. There is a experience level in the game, each level up gives you skill points that you can spend in a skill tech tree. These perks are only for shamans. Collecting cheese rewards experience as do shaman saves. When you get enough shaman saves you get the hardmode which disables some of the crucial abilities shamans need for making stable bridges. In exchange for that, you get a totem which you can prebuild and summon directly into the game instead of wasting time to build it while in the game and racing against time.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Opinions

In my opinion I feel that this game is in fact very fun and very stress releasing to play. It is not those kind of competitive games where you have to use your head and get stressed out. I normally play this casually, unless you are some sort of diehard fan you would probably not spend more than 2-4 hours on this game in my experience. Other than that, this game is fun in all aspects. I like the rewarding sense of achievement when I complete a difficult task of collecting the cheese and bringing it home in a gamemode called bootcamp. This is a factor which draws me back into the game and makes me excited when I feel like playing some Transformice. This is the end of my review, thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Whether or not I recommend this game is very dependant on what you want out of it. If you're the competitive type who doesn't like luck based outcomes or you're looking for a good community to interact with than this is definitely no longer the game for you as the new shaman skills and player inventory make winning a complete toss up, the leaderboard is full of hackers, and the community is absolutely atrocious. That being said, there are also many good things transformice has going for it, my favourite being shamaning itself. You basically have to use different items connected by different types of anchors to build structures that the other players (mice) can traverse in order to complete the level. The difficulty of this increases as you unlock new shaman modes, should you choose to use them. Each new shaman mode will both impair and also add to your abilities. You can get extremely creative while as the shaman, and it's honestly the only reason I played this game for 4 years. The other players will 'race' in order to see who can get to the hole first, but there are so many factors that cannot be anticipated making this quite frustrating if you're trying for first. Random bubbles/balls/various other randomly spawned objects or even the shaman himself (95% of people cannot shaman well)  will constantly stop you no matter how good you are at the game. There are also a number of fun minigames such as soccer and pictionary, which can be fun if little kids and foreigners spamming insults at you is no deterrent.

Other things to note:
- Glitches. LOTS of glitches.
- Lags worse than planetside 2
- Mostly because the servers are in france (but for some reason most players are brazillian?)
+ You get to play mouse dress up

tl;dr game used to be 10/10 now its ded

reviewText:
A game that is easy to play, yet hard to master, A game that is both cute, funny, and interesting to play. A game that manage to please both casual and hardcore players. What kind of beautiful magic created Transformice ?

I don't know how they did it, but i sure know it's a success. You get sucked in by the cute mice with tiny hats and funny animaitons. You enjoy running along whatever contraption the Shaman manages to make, and grab the cheese. Then you start getting interested in some advanced mechanics like wall jumping. And you start to get greedy, you try to get the cheese first and become competitive. Finally, after a few rounds, you discover the whole new realm of shamaning, and understand how much complexity there is in that.

The game is 100% free (the only stuff you can buy with actual money are cosmetic items), so you have no excuse to not try it. And i dare you to not find something you like in it. Maybe you're gonna enjoy being a part of group of cute little mice that dance, and laugh and sometimes cry after an horrible jump into a bottomless pit. Maybe you're gonna enjoy the brain burning aspect of being the shaman and solving maps to help your fellow mice get their precious cheese. Maybe you're gonna get competitive, and strive for 1st place everytime, by taking insane risks to scalp a fraction of a second in your completion time.

Really, Transformice is the best game to play with group of people with different video game knowledge. Everyone can find something in it.
